feasts: Martyrdom of St. Febronia the Ascetic
Departure of Sts. Bioukha and Tayaban
1 Epep.summary: St. Febronia, a virgin ascetic, was martyred under Diocletian after refusing to worship idols. Sts. Bioukha and Tayaban, priests of Tunah, lived virtuously and departed in peace.

feasts: Departure of St. Thaddaeus, the Apostle
2 Epep.summary: St. Thaddaeus, one of the twelve apostles, preached the Gospel, converted many, and suffered persecution before departing in peace.

feasts: Departure of St. Kyrillos I, 24th Pope of Alexandria
Departure of St. Celestine, Pope of Rome
3 Epep.summary: St. Kyrillos I, a pillar of faith, refuted heresies and led the Council of Ephesus. St. Celestine, bishop of Rome, opposed Nestorius and was restored to his throne.

feasts: Commemoration of Relocation of Sts. Apakir and John's Relics
4 Epep.summary: The relics of martyrs Sts. Apakir and John were relocated to a church by St. Mark under St. Cyril's guidance, leading to many conversions.

feasts: Martyrdom of Sts. Peter and Paul, the Apostles
5 Epep.summary: St. Peter, a fervent apostle, and St. Paul, a former persecutor turned preacher, were martyred in Rome under Nero.

feasts: Martyrdom of St. Aoulimpas, the Apostle
Martyrdom of St. Theodosia and companions
6 Epep.summary: St. Aoulimpas, a disciple of St. Peter, was crucified under Nero. St. Theodosia and others were martyred after confessing Christ.

feasts: Departure of St. Shenouda, the Archimandrite
Martyrdom of St. Ignatius, Bishop of Antioch
7 Epep.summary: St. Shenouda, a monastic leader, attended the Council of Ephesus. St. Ignatius was martyred in Rome under Trajan.

feasts: Departure of St. Anba Bishoy
Martyrdom of Sts. Piroou, Athom, Balanah, Epime
Departure of St. Cyrus
8 Epep.summary: St. Bishoy, a desert monk, saw Christ in a vision. Sts. Piroou, Athom, Balanah, and Epime were martyred for their faith. St. Cyrus lived as a hermit.

feasts: Martyrdom of St. Simon Cleophas, the Apostle
Departure of St. Cladianus, 9th Pope
9 Epep.summary: St. Simon Cleophas, bishop of Jerusalem, was martyred under Trajan. St. Cladianus served as a righteous patriarch.

feasts: Martyrdom of St. Theodore, Bishop of Pentapolis
Martyrdom of St. Theodore, Bishop of Corinth
Departure of Anba Gabriel VII, 95th Pope
10 Epep.summary: St. Theodore of Pentapolis and St. Theodore of Corinth were martyred for their faith. Anba Gabriel VII renovated monasteries.

feasts: Martyrdom of Sts. John and Simon
Departure of St. Isaiah, the hermit
11 Epep.summary: Sts. John and Simon, cousins, were martyred under Diocletian. St. Isaiah lived as a hermit in Scetis.

feasts: Commemoration of Archangel Michael
Martyrdom of St. Abba Hour El-Siriakousy
12 Epep.summary: Archangel Michael is celebrated as a protector. St. Abba Hour was martyred after confessing Christ.

feasts: Departure of St. Pisentius, Bishop of Qift
Martyrdom of St. Apamon of Toukh
Martyrdom of St. Abba Shenoute
13 Epep.summary: St. Pisentius was an ascetic bishop. St. Apamon and St. Shenoute were martyred for their faith during early Arab rule.

feasts: Martyrdom of St. Procopius of Jerusalem
Departure of St. Peter V, 83rd Patriarch
14 Epep.summary: St. Procopius was martyred under Diocletian. St. Peter V led the church peacefully.

feasts: Departure of St. Ephraem El-Soriani
Martyrdom of Sts. Cyriacus and Julietta
Martyrdom of St. Horesius of Soul
15 Epep.summary: St. Ephraem, a Syrian monk, met St. Basil. Sts. Cyriacus, Julietta, and Horesius were martyred for their faith.

feasts: The Departure of St. John, of the Golden Gospel
The Recovery of the Holy Relics of St. George, the Great Martyr
16 Epep.summary: St. John, born in Rome, received a golden Gospel from his father. He became a monk, lived ascetically, and returned to his parents’ home disguised as a beggar, revealing his identity before his death. His relics were later enshrined in a church. The relics of St. George were brought to his church in Old Cairo by Fr. Marcus, fulfilling a vision, with many miracles manifested.

feasts: The Martyrdom of St. Euphemia
17 Epep.summary: St. Euphemia was martyred after boldly condemning idol worship and expressing compassion for persecuted Christians. She endured severe torture before giving up her soul to the Lord.

feasts: The Martyrdom of St. James the Apostle, Bishop of Jerusalem
18 Epep.summary: St. James, son of Alphaeus and bishop of Jerusalem, was known as James the Just. He presided over the Council of Jerusalem and was martyred by Jews who beat him after he proclaimed Christ’s divinity.

feasts: The Martyrdom of Sts. Bidaba, Bishop of Qift, Anba Andrew, and Anba Christodoulas
The Martyrdom of St. Pantaleemon, the Physician
The Departure of Pope Youanis X, 85th Patriarch of Alexandria
19 Epep.summary: St. Bidaba, a bishop, with Andrew and Christodoulas, were martyred under Diocletian after confessing Christ. St. Pantaleemon, a physician, performed miracles and was martyred after refusing to deny Christ. Pope Youanis X, a righteous patriarch, served from 1363 to 1369 and was buried in Old Cairo.

feasts: The Martyrdom of St. Theodore of Shotep
20 Epep.summary: St. Theodore, born in Shotep, became a general in Antioch. He killed a serpent to save a widow’s sons, confessed Christ, and was martyred under Emperor Lucianus. His body was later enshrined in churches.

feasts: The Commemoration of the Lady, the Virgin Mary
The Departure of St. Sisinnios (Sosenius), the Eunich
21 Epep.summary: The Virgin Mary is commemorated as the mother of Christ. St. Sisinnios, a palace eunuch under Theodosius, served St. Cyril at the Council of Ephesus, gave his wealth to the poor, and departed in peace.

feasts: The Commemoration of the Martyrdom of St. Macarius, the Son of Basilides (Wasilides) the Minister
The Commemoration of the Martyrdom of St. Leontius of Tripoli (Lawendius)
22 Epep.summary: St. Macarius, son of a chancellor, was martyred under Diocletian after refusing to worship idols, performing miracles during his torture. St. Leontius, a soldier from Tripoli, preached Christ, was tortured, and died in prison, his body preserved by a Christian woman.

feasts: Martyrdom of St. Longinus the Soldier
Martyrdom of St. Marina of Antioch
23 Epep.summary: St. Longinus, a soldier at Christ’s crucifixion, believed and was martyred. St. Marina overcame the devil and was martyred.

feasts: Martyrdom of St. Apanoub
Departure of St. Simeon I, 42nd Pope
24 Epep.summary: St. Apanoub, a young martyr, gave his wealth to the poor. St. Simeon I performed miracles and built churches.

feasts: Departure of St. Thecla
Martyrdom of Sts. Isaac, Hilaria, Thecla, Mouji, Antonius, Abakragoun, Domadius
Consecration of St. Mercurius Church
Departure of St. Palamon
25 Epep.summary: St. Thecla followed St. Paul. Sts. Isaac, Hilaria, Thecla, Mouji, Antonius, Abakragoun, and Domadius were martyred. St. Mercurius’ church was consecrated. St. Palamon mentored St. Pachomius.

feasts: Departure of St. Joseph, the Carpenter
Departure of St. Timothy, 22nd Pope
26 Epep.summary: St. Joseph, betrothed to Virgin Mary, died at 111. St. Timothy refuted Arian heresy.

feasts: Consecration of St. Abba Fam’s Church
Martyrdom of St. Apamon
27 Epep.summary: St. Abba Fam’s church was consecrated. St. Apamon was martyred after enduring torture.

feasts: Departure of St. Mary Magdalene
28 Epep.summary: St. Mary Magdalene, freed from demons, served Christ and preached after His resurrection.

feasts: Commemoration of St. Andrew’s Relics Translocation
Martyrdom of St. Ouarshenoufa
29 Epep.summary: St. Andrew’s relics were moved to Constantinople. St. Ouarshenoufa was martyred for destroying an imperial edict.

feasts: Martyrdom of Sts. Mercurius and Ephraem
30 Epep.summary: Sts. Mercurius and Ephraem, monks and kinsmen, were martyred for rejecting Arian offerings.
